name: Rice Stem Borer
description: Stem borers are moths whose larvae bore into rice stems, affecting plant development. Major species include Scirpophaga incertulas and Chilo suppressalis.
damage: Causes 'deadheart' during vegetative stage and 'whitehead' during reproductive stage, reducing tiller and grain production.

biological: Release of Trichogramma japonicum egg parasitoids
Encourage predators like spiders, ants, and mirid bugs
chemical: Use Chlorpyriphos 20 EC at 2 ml/L during early infestation
soaking of the roots of the seedlings in 0.02 chlorpyriphos for 12-14 hrs before transplanting (30 days protection).

Apply the following insecticides based on fipronil, chlorpyrifos or chlorantraniliprole either as granules or spray once the threshold is reached (25-30 male moths/trap/week). Do not use broad-spectrum insecticides to fight pests.
cultural: Remove and destroy stubbles after harvest
Use light traps to catch adult moths
Apply nitrogen fertilizer and manure moderately
organic: Use pheromone traps to disrupt mating

name: Rice Leaf Folder
description: The larva of this pest folds rice leaves and feeds inside, reducing photosynthesis.
damage: Results in yellowing and drying of leaves and poor grain filling.

organic: Use pheromone traps at field boundaries

name: Rice Blast
description: Caused by Pyricularia oryzae, this fungus affects all above-ground parts of the plant.
damage: Reduces yield by damaging leaves, nodes, and panicles. Severe infections cause lodging and grain loss.

biological: Apply Pseudomonas fluorescens as seed and foliar spray
Use Trichoderma spp. to reduce pathogen buildup
chemical: Use Propiconazole at early flowering stage
cultural: Maintain control of weeds and alternative hosts
organic: Spray neem and garlic extract mix
Adopt SRI method to improve plant health

name: Bacterial Leaf Blight
description: Caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae, this disease spreads rapidly through wounds and water.
damage: Symptoms include yellowing and drying of leaves from tips down, reducing photosynthetic area.

biological: Promote antagonistic bacteria like Bacillus spp.
chemical: Spray Streptocycline (100 ppm) + Copper oxychloride (3 g/L)
cultural: Use resistant varieties and clean seeds
organic: Apply cow urine + turmeric foliar mix
Use compost tea sprays to suppress bacteria

name: Brown Spot
description: Caused by Bipolaris oryzae, brown spot affects leaves, grains, and other aerial parts.
damage: Causes brown lesions on leaves and grains, poor seed germination, and yield loss.

biological: Apply Pseudomonas fluorescens as foliar spray
chemical: Spray Mancozeb 75 WP at 2.5g/L of water
organic: Use neem oil + garlic extract mix

name: Aphid
description: Tiny insects that suck sap from leaves and stems; often found in clusters.
damage: Cause yellowing, leaf curling, and sooty mold due to honeydew secretion.

name: Bacterial Panicle Blight
description: Caused by Burkholderia glumae, affects panicles during flowering.
damage: Results in empty or discolored grains and panicle sterility.

biological: Use Bacillus subtilis as biological control agent
chemical: No highly effective chemicals, but copper compounds may suppress

name: Dirty Panicle
description: A mixture of several fungal infections causes the panicles to appear dirty or moldy.
damage: Affects grain quality and reduces market value.

organic: Apply cow dung slurry + neem cake

name: Rice Hispa
description: Small beetle whose larvae mine inside leaves, while adults feed on leaf surface.
damage: Leaves appear streaked and whitish; reduces photosynthesis.

chemical: control population using following active ingredient: malathion, cypermethrin, fenthoate
cultural: Early planting to avoid peak population
Cut the shoot tip to prevent egg-laying
Apply a crop rotation to break the life cycle of the pest

name: Narrow Brown Spot
description: Caused by Cercospora oryzae, appears as narrow brown lesions on leaves.
damage: Reduces photosynthetic area, may lead to reduced grain quality and yield.

biological: Apply Trichoderma spp. to suppress fungal growth
chemical: Spray Mancozeb or Carbendazim during early symptoms

name: Rice Leafhopper
description: Sap-sucking insect that also transmits viral diseases like rice tungro.
damage: Yellowing and curling of leaves; vector for viral diseases.

biological: Encourage natural predators like spiders and wasps

name: Rice Gall Midge
description: Larvae form silvery galls instead of panicles, reducing yield.
damage: Silver shoots that do not produce grain.

chemical: Apply Carbofuran granules at seedling stage
organic: Ash dusting at base of plants

name: Armyworm
description: Caterpillars that feed on rice foliage during night.
damage: Causes defoliation; severe infestations destroy entire crop.

name: Bacterial Leaf Streak
description: Caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzicola, characterized by narrow, water-soaked lesions.
damage: Lesions coalesce, reducing leaf function and yield.

organic: Foliar spray of turmeric + whey solution

name: Brown Planthopper
description: Major pest of rice that sucks sap and transmits viruses.
damage: Causes 'hopper burn', leading to patches of dead plants.

name: Dead Heart
description: Central shoot dries while lower leaves remain green; symptom of stem borer attack.
damage: Non-productive tillers; major yield loss.

name: False Smut
description: Caused by Ustilaginoidea virens, forms greenish-black spore balls on panicles.
damage: Reduces grain quality; affects milling.

name: Normal
description: Crop appears healthy with no visible symptoms of pests or diseases.
damage: None

organic: Continue organic compost and neem support

name: Rice Leaf Roller
description: Larvae roll leaves and feed inside, forming white streaks.
damage: Reduces photosynthesis, leading to stunted growth.

name: Sheath Blight
description: Caused by Rhizoctonia solani, appears as oval lesions on leaf sheath.
damage: Reduces photosynthesis, increases lodging.

organic: Use compost + cow urine foliar spray

name: Tungro
description: Caused by rice tungro bacilliform and spherical viruses; transmitted by green leafhoppers.
damage: Stunted plants, yellow-orange leaves, poor grain filling.

name: Undefine
description: no disease found
damage: None
